AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Trembling, or Quaking aspen is said to be the most widespread tree in North America and it is cited as the most abundant tree in Minnesota, although when settlers arrived, it apparently ranked second behind tamarack. Trembling aspen can grow in a large range of habitat types. It is an early successional species that grows quickly and rarely lives beyond 100 years. Aspen's special power is its ability to spread vegetatively by sprouting stems from its shallow root system, a process called "root suckering". Through this process, a single tree established by seed can spread over an acre or more. Since all the stems originate from a common root system, they are all genetically identical and collectively called a clone. In Fishlake National Forest in Utah, a massive clone of Populus tremuloides (confirmed as one individual by DNA testing) covers 170 acres and has over 47,000 stems all of which share one massive root system. The chalky powder on the bark can be used as a sunscreen; it has a power similar to spf 5. The petioles, or leaf stalks, are flattened instead of round, which causes the leaves to flap and flutter in the wind, hence the name “quaking” aspen.
Smooth, greenish white to cream, become more chalky with age, in old age furrowed (beginning near base), dark brown or gray, roughened by numerous wart-like excrescences

Unisexual catkins, each tree bearing either male or female. Male catkins pendulous, 3-8 cm long sessile. Female catkins pendulous, 3-6 cm long in flower, becoming 4-15 cm long in fruit, sessile, rachis hairy
2-valved ovoid capsule, 3.5-6 mm long, releasing seeds early/mid-May to early June

Alternate, simple, thin, ovate to orbicular, short-acuminate, truncate to broad-cuneate at base, 1 1/2 to 3" long and wide, finely glandular-serrate, lustrous dark green above, glabrous and glaucescent beneath,
Unusually long and flattened petiolet which causes the leaf to "tremble" or "quake" in the wind, greenish or white bark

ThemeEntityData.Description: Trembling, or Quaking aspen is said to be the most widespread tree in North America and it is cited as the most abundant tree in Minnesota, although when settlers arrived, it apparently ranked second behind tamarack. Trembling aspen can grow in a large range of habitat types. It is an early successional species that grows quickly and rarely lives beyond 100 years. Aspen's special power is its ability to spread vegetatively by sprouting stems from its shallow root system, a process called "root suckering". Through this process, a single tree established by seed can spread over an acre or more. Since all the stems originate from a common root system, they are all genetically identical and collectively called a clone. In Fishlake National Forest in Utah, a massive clone of Populus tremuloides (confirmed as one individual by DNA testing) covers 170 acres and has over 47,000 stems all of which share one massive root system. The chalky powder on the bark can be used as a sunscreen; it has a power similar to spf 5. The petioles, or leaf stalks, are flattened instead of round, which causes the leaves to flap and flutter in the wind, hence the name “quaking” aspen.
